metadata.case_name: Holder of Taluk Kakwara v. Banaili Raj

facts.text: Respondents obtained a decree for Rs. 11,587-14-6 against appellant for arrears of rent and cess.
Respondents applied for execution of decree by attachment and sale of Taluk Kakwara.
On August 29, 1939, appellant filed objection under section 47 CPC alleging Taluk Kakwara held on Ghatwali tenure could not be sold in execution of money decree.
Objection held too wide as not all Ghatwali tenures inalienable.
On May 31, 1940, appellant filed fresh petition under section 47 claiming Taluk Kakwara held under Government Ghatwali tenure.
Subordinate Judge of Bhagalpur held Taluk Kakwara Zamindari Ghatwali under Raja of Kharakpur, overruled objection in Mis. Case No. 174 of 1939 on 13th July 1940.

Appeal to High Court of Patna (Appeal No. 238 of 1940), Manohar Lal J. inclined to allow (Government Ghatwali), Shearer J. inclined to dismiss (Zamindari Ghatwali), referred to Chatterjee J. who held Zamindari Ghatwali, dismissed appeal on 22nd November 1944.
Appellant obtained leave to appeal to Privy Council, transferred to Supreme Court.
Taluk Kakwara appertains to Mahalat Kharakpur; appellant present holder; respondents represent Banaili Raj which acquired Mahalat Kharakpur.
Ghatwali tenures originated in Mughal period for police/military services guarding mountain passes.
In Kharakpur, Ghatwali tenures alienable with assent of Zamindar per custom in Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy.
In 1765, East India Company secured Dewani; Mozaffar Ali Raja of Kharakpur rebelled in 1766, subdued 1768, estate managed by Company till restored to grandson Kadir Ali in 1780.
1776/1777: Captain Browne granted Sanad (Exhibit 1) for Taluk Kakwara (22 villages) to Rankoo Singh and Bhairo Singh (ghatwals) at fixed jama Rs. 245-12-15, duties include protection of tenants.
1780: Raja Kadir Ali granted Sanad (Exhibit 1a) to same grantees for Ghatwali service tenure (16 mauzas), 177 musketeers/archers, fixed quit-rent Rs. 245-12-15 inclusive of Zamindari rasoom.
1789/1790 decennial settlement, 1796 permanent under Regulation I of 1793; Ghatwali lands included in Zamindari assessment.
Lists in 1860 and 1863 by Government show Kakwara as one of 98 Ghatwali Mahals appertaining to Kharakpur.
Handwa, Lachmipur, Chandan Katoria treated as Government Ghatwalis, took Sanads from Collectors not Raja.
Dispute: Whether Taluk Kakwara Government Ghatwali (appellant) or Zamindari Ghatwali (respondents).

legal_issues.text: Whether Taluk Kakwara was a Government Ghatwali tenure (inalienable) or Zamindari Ghatwali held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur (alienable with assent of Zamindar).

petitioner_arguments.text: Taluk Kakwara held on Government Ghatwali tenure, inalienable and could not be sold in execution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Narayan Singh v. Niranjan Chakravarti; Captain Browne's Sanad created Government tenure

petitioner_arguments.text: Captain Browne's Sanad (1777) created Government Ghatwali; Raja Kadir Ali's Sanad confirmatory.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Seal indicates Government grant; payment to Government treasury

respondent_arguments.text: Taluk Kakwara is Zamindari Ghatwali under Raja of Kharakpur, alienable with assent of Zamindar.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy; custom in Kharakpur

respondent_arguments.text: Captain Browne's Sanad confirmed existing Zamindari tenure; Raja Kadir Ali's Sanad regularised as Zamindari Ghatwali.

court_reasoning.text: Ghatwali tenures vary: Government direct inalienable; Kharakpur Zamindari alienable with Zamindar assent per custom.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custom judicially recognised in Kali Pershad; distinguished from Handwa.

court_reasoning.text: Captain Browne's Sanad (1777) likely confirmed existing tenure during interregnum; duties akin to Zamindari.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No specification of armed force; addressed to Zamindars.

court_reasoning.text: Raja Kadir Ali's Sanad (1780) clarified as Zamindari: inclusive rasoom, apportionment, different villages, 98 Ghatwals took from Raja.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government never questioned; even if Government originally, released post-Sanad.

court_reasoning.text: Permanent Settlement included in Zamindari; Government lists as Kharakpur Ghatwali; prior cases treated as Zamindari.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguished from Handwa (no rasoom, direct to treasury, Collector Sanad).

holdings.text: Taluk Kakwara is Zamindari Ghatwali tenure, alienable with assent of Zamindar per Kharakpur custom.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kali Pershad Singh v. Anund Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Kharakpur Ghatwali alienable with Zamindar assent; custom well-established.
Handwa Government Ghatwali inalienable; classes of Ghatwalis; no application to Kakwara.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Lelanund Singh v. Government Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Nature of Zamindari/Ghatwali; Kharakpur Ghatwalis part of Zamindari assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Leelanund Singh v. Thakoor Munranjan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Kakwara part of Kharakpur Zamindari; dependent taluk.
Kakwara perpetual hereditary Zamindari Ghatwali; Browne Sanad confirmatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rani Sonabati Kumari v. Raja Kirtyanand Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Handwa Government Ghatwali; differences from Kakwara.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for objection in execution proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Permanent Settlement Regulation
statutes_cited.relevance: Ghatwali lands included in Zamindari assessment; no resumption.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Regulation
statutes_cited.relevance: Government claim to resume Ghatwali lands rejected.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court and lower court orders overruling appellant's objection; Taluk Kakwara held alienable as Zamindari Ghatwali with Zamindar assent, permitting execution sale.

key_quotes.text: "Ghatwali tenures held under the Zamindar of Kharakpur were, by custom judicially recognised, alienable with the assent of the Zamindar."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Taluk Kakwara was, in its origin, a Zamindari Ghatwali tenure and continued to be so and was in fact treated as such down to the present time."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A sale at the instance of the Zamindar in execution of a decree for arrears of rent necessarily implies the existence of such assent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
